description.plain:
If you haven’t heard about Vince Staples yet, you’ve been missing out. Hailing from the LBC, Vince is one of the single best young talents that the West Coast has to offer.

Vince has been making waves since his initial breakout with the Odd Future crew and has recently even signed a deal with Def-Jam and the legendary No I.D.’s label Artium. Everything you need to know about how dope Mr. Staples can be found in his ridiculous, breakout verse on “Hive” by Earl Sweatshirt. While you’re at it, Vince has released a slew of projects over the course of the past few years, including the Shyne Coldchain series, (both 1 and 2), and the Hell Can Wait EP. It all culminates to his debut album, Summertime 06.

After the release of Summertime ‘06, Vince would go on to release his Prima Donna EP which would feature one of hip-hop’s biggest artists, A$AP Rocky.

Vince would then go on to release Big Fish Theory on June 23rd, 2017. The album featured even bigger names than the Prima Donna EP. Kendrick Lamar, Juicy J, Ty Dolla $ign, and even another project with A$AP Rocky on it.

Vince has a rather small award count, with only winning one and being nominated for another. In 2014 BET would give him the award ‘Best Impact Track’ for his song “Kingdom”. The Black Reel Awards would later nominate him for ‘Best Original or Adapted Song’ with his song “Waiting for My Moment” which was adapted from the movie Creed.

Despite him believing he should have won or been nominated for a Grammy for his album, Big Fish Theory, it was not nominated. Vince doesn’t think it should have been nominated for ‘Best Rap Album of the Year’ but rather ‘Best Electronic Album of the Year’.

Vince started off March of 2018 with a huge bang. He released a song called “Get The Fuck Off My Dick” which had a $2 million GoFundMe page attached to it with a line saying “Get off my dick or fund my lifestyle”.

songs.title: Norf Norf

description.plain:
One of three Clams Casino produced tracks on Summertime ‘06, “Norf Norf” finds Vince Staples pridefully repping his origins; the Norfside of Long Beach, CA. Vince talked about the city in an interview with self-titled:


[Long Beach is] the suburbs—not in the sense of safety or of how it looks, but in the sense of how it’s set up. Everyone knows everyone; it’s a small place, not one you get out of. And it’s really difficult, whether you talk economically, racially—it’s not the same as LA at all.

Nobody do nothing in Long Beach but gangbang. But we’ve been doing that our whole life.


In October of 2016, a video of a Christian mother analyzing the lyrics surfaced. The video went viral and the song was made popular again, a year after its release.

songs.full_title: Señorita by Vince Staples (Ft. Future & Snoh Aalegra)
songs.title: Señorita

description.plain:
First performed during Vince’s performance at the Fader Fort during his 2015 SXSW run, “Señorita” gets the honor as the first single from Vince’s debut studio album Summertime 06.

A blend of Staples' West Side style mixes with the sample of Atlanta superstar Future’s hook, and the track also features unaccredited vocals from fellow Atrium label-mate Snoh Aalegra on the outro.

songs.full_title: Big Fish by Vince Staples (Ft. Juicy J)
songs.title: Big Fish

description.plain:
“Big Fish” is the second single off of Vince’s 2nd studio album Big Fish Theory. Vince muses on the ways in which rap has changed his life and how far he’s come. On the same day of the song’s release, Vince announced that his highly anticipated album would be released on June 23.

The song’s music video depicts Vince sitting and rapping on a sinking sailboat in shark-infested waters.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0l9kzS_B7gg

songs.full_title: Yeah Right by Vince Staples (Ft. Kendrick Lamar & KUČKA)
songs.title: Yeah Right

description.plain:
“Yeah Right” is the 7th track on Vince Staples' sophomore album, Big Fish Theory. The track is a collaboration with Kendrick Lamar, Kučka, electronic record producer Flume, and PC Music affiliate, SOPHIE. This marks the third three-way collaboration between Vince, KUČKA, and Flume, following “Smoke and Retribution” and a Triple J ‘Like a Version’ of Ghost Town DJ’s ‘My Boo’ in 2016.

In “Yeah Right,” Staples questions whether other rappers are actually living the life they broadcast. He also assesses the morality and intelligence of modern culture by discussing its fixation on drugs (which he abstains from using), money, and plastic surgery.

songs.title: Blue Suede

description.plain:
“Blue Suede” is the lead single for Vince Staples' 2014 Def Jam EP Hell Can Wait.

The track opens with a blood-curdling synth and couples it with the bone-breaking thump of Me & the Biz Born to Roll.

There’s been much speculation as to whether this song is an extended metaphor of the hood life, a mockery of fake rappers that portray that image, or Vince just being Vince.

songs.full_title: Lift Me Up by Vince Staples
songs.title: Lift Me Up

description.plain:
“Lift Me Up” was premiered by Vince Staples at a show in Las Vegas on May 15th, 2015.

Vince contrasts the rich, upper class lifestyle with the grit of his own living in Long Beach in the summer of 2006.

Summer of 2006, the beginning of the end of everything I though I knew. Youth was stolen from my city that Summer and Im left alone to tell the story.

songs.title: Summertime

description.plain:
After being driven crazy and wanting to build a life with the woman mentioned throughout the album, the final track on the first disc touches on a lighter side of Vince as he brings his insecurities and pain to the front lines.

As Vince stated in a note on his Instagram, one of the main catalysts of change during this time was love:

Love tore us all apart. Love for self, love for separation, love for the little we all had, love for each other, where we came from.

description.plain:
Vince raps over a g funk/detroit techno fusion beat provided by Jimmy Edgar.

The track has Vince driving around town in a BMW 745i, an early-mid 2000s model in BMW’s luxury sedan 7-series, musing about his relationships to women.

His usual nihilism shines throughout the track with the feeling that although love is possible, it is too tricky of an obstacle for him right now to deal with the way he wishes he could.

songs.full_title: Prima Donna by Vince Staples (Ft. A$AP Rocky)
songs.title: Prima Donna

description.plain:
“Prima Donna” is the title-track for Vince’s 2016 EP. This song features A$AP Rocky, making it the first time the two have collaborated. Vince told Zane Lowe that he picked this feature based on voice.

 In 2015, Rocky told MTV that Summer ‘06 “fits the mold.” Perhaps it led to this collaboration.

They’ve [Earl Sweatshirt and Vince Staples] got their own styles and shit so it was just dope to get diversity and variety.

Vince premiered a 10-minute long short film accompanying the song on Vevo:

http://www.vevo.com/watch/USUV71602545?utm_medium=embed_player&utm_content=watermark&syn_id=af330f2c-5617-4e57-81b5-4a6edbef07cc

songs.full_title: Jump Off the Roof by Vince Staples (Ft. Snoh Aalegra)
songs.title: Jump Off the Roof
songs.title_with_featured: Jump Off the Roof (Ft. Snoh Aalegra)

description.plain:
Coming off a song like “Dopeman”, it’s fitting the next track focuses on Vince’s addictions and vices. From love & sex to drugs, Vince questions his control over these things, while finally coming to the conclusion he needs a wake up call. In this case he has to metaphorically “jump off the roof”.

The bridge is sung by fellow label mate Snoh Aalegra. Vince said in an interview with HNHH:

She’s definitely part of the family. That’s my friend. Snoh’s great.

songs.full_title: Love Can Be... by Vince Staples (Ft. Damon Albarn, Kilo Kish & Ray J)
songs.title: Love Can Be...
songs.title_with_featured: Love Can Be... (Ft. Damon Albarn, Kilo Kish & Ray J)

description.plain:
Vince Staples has worked with the production duo GTA again after a previous collaboration together on “Little Bit of This.” With vocals from Gorillaz member Damon Albarn and Kilo Kish, “Love Can Be…” breaks down genres and depicts a bleak outlook on love.

  


The song also features vocals from Ray J, whom Staples is known for praising in several interviews. When he was asked, back in 2015, about trying to get a Ray J feature, Vince responded:

We don’t need a Ray J feature. We ain’t ready for nothin' like that. We just need a cosign.

https://youtu.be/6JfKDt9KsF4

songs.full_title: Crabs in a Bucket by Vince Staples (Ft. Kilo Kish)
songs.title: Crabs in a Bucket
songs.title_with_featured: Crabs in a Bucket (Ft. Kilo Kish)

description.plain:
The “crabs in a bucket” mentality can be described as an “if I can’t have it, neither can you” train of thought. Crabs trapped in a bucket will grapple and climb over each other trying to escape, but this ultimately ensures that none of them succeeds. The reference is an analogy to the widespread practice of putting others down in an attempt to elevate oneself.

For Vince, the metaphor could describe the experience of African Americans stuck in urban poverty, or Vince’s own experience in the West Coast hip hop scene.

songs.full_title: Get the Fuck Off My Dick by Vince Staples
songs.title: Get the Fuck Off My Dick
songs.title_with_featured: Get the Fuck Off My Dick

description.plain:
In a spectacular move, this single was released a day after Vince Staples set up a GoFundMe campaign called #GTFOMD in response to criticism on his music and his stage shows. He claimed to retire early (“you’ll never hear from me again. no songs, no interviews”) if $2 million would be raised – if not, he could do whatever he wanted. On the campaign video, he stated:

Get off my dick or fund my lifestyle

On this song, he details the backlash from critics, music journalists, awards and haters. He boldly claims pride for his work:

Hard to tell which one more perfect, man, my art or my bitch

After his Prima Donna EP in 2016 and the 2017 album Big Fish Theory where he left the more trap-oriented sound from his earlier projects, he faced criticism concerning his electronic (and more experimental) production. However, on this song, the instrumental is a hard-hitting, sparse and rather conventional trap beat.

The #GTFOMD campaign featured a promotional video and a set of written terms which Vince would agree to:
https://vimeo.com/258872772

For 2M I agree to do the following:
- Move to Palmdale
- Buy a Honda
- Year supply of soups for the homies locked down
- Buy a puppy

At the release of this song, the campaign had raised around $1000, which made Vince mock his haters on Twitter:

https://twitter.com/vincestaples/status/971481466050940933

Vince has always dealt with criticism in a very direct way and doesn’t shy away from battling haters on Twitter. He’s also known for his sharp comments – whether it be about old-school hip hop, other rappers' freestyles or homophobia. Vince is one of the most outspoken rappers of his time. On a Pitchfork podcast, he stated to be more famous for his interviews than for his music.

description.plain:
Perhaps continuing from the last track, Vince has fallen in love with the woman who has driven him crazy simply for sex. His love interest and struggle to keep her will come up later on the album. Vince talked about the record’s concept in an interview with DJ Booth:

https://youtu.be/LBVuoVmCuec

Fellow label mate Jhene Aiko assists Vince to provide the female perspective of the relationship while simultaneously warning him of his motives.

songs.title: Home

description.plain:
“Home” is the last track on the Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse soundtrack, and also the song used in the trailers and is colloquially known as the theme song for the film.

The song chronicles the plight of a black and Latino vigilante who is torn between doing what’s good for the world, and what it means to be hated by the cops both because of one’s vigilante status and one’s race and ethnicity.

songs.title: Smile

description.plain: On the third track on Prima Donna, Vince talks about how he’s of ashamed about how he left everything he knew to try and chase fame. Like many artists, he notices that his life in the limelight has ultimately changed him. Vince has talked several times about his hardships as a teenager and his unhappiness at a young age, but even now that he has left his old lifestyle, home and his friends for the money and the fame, he still can’t find happiness.

songs.full_title: Loco by Vince Staples (Ft. Kilo Kish)
songs.title: Loco

description.plain:
“Loco” is the fourth song on Prima Donna. Here, Staples talks about the crazy side of his life and how he continues to cherish it.

Note the title’s similarity to that of “Loca,” from 2015’s Summertime ‘06. The titles are the two variations of the word “crazy” in Spanish—"loca" being the feminine form and “loco” being the masculine form.

Also shared between the two songs is Kilo Kish on vocals.

songs.title: Alyssa Interlude

description.plain:
The intro for this song samples an interview from Amy Winehouse, where she talks about her experiences with love.  This interview was featured in the documentary Amy, which inspired Vince to make Prima Donna

I saw the Amy Winehouse documentary and I was like, this is sad. This happens a lot. Thought of all the other times it happened, and I was like, I wanna make a little movie thing about it. I’m gonna make a soundtrack. That was Prima Donna.
– Vince Staples, in an interview with Vulture

Vince has previously explained his love for Winehouse’s music:

I don’t really know why I like this album so much in all honesty, but it’s great. Every song puts you in a specific mood that you can’t escape from until it is over. Depressing in a sense but for all the right reasons. A true artist can make you feel both their sorrow and their happiness. You feel all of these emotions back to back and transform them into these stories without noticing the shift. Definitely someone who was gone too soon. R.I.P.

songs.full_title: Don't Get Chipped by Vince Staples
songs.title: Don’t Get Chipped

description.plain:
“Don’t Get Chipped” serves as the third track to Vince Staples' third studio album, FM! Produced by CuBeatz and Kenny Beats, the song features Jay Rock on the chorus, and marks a first collaboration between the two West Coast rappers.

The track’s title is in reference to the slang term “getting chipped,” which refers to getting shot—often in a gang altercation. Staples is no stranger to gang activity as he has been a member of the Crips. These themes are represented in Jay Rock’s chours:

Represent my location
Don’t get chipped, don’t get chipped, don’t get chipped…

Furthermore, Vince also interpolates a few lyrics from his 2017 single, “BagBak,” on his second verse:

Who done did it like I did it from the hometown?
Started dead broke, but I’m on now

songs.full_title: SAMO by Vince Staples (Ft. A$AP Rocky & Kilo Kish)
songs.title: SAMO

description.plain:
“SAMO” is the ninth track off of Big Fish Theory. The title is most likely a reference to a graffiti tag  developed by renowned artist Jean-Michel Basquiat and his friend Al Diaz. According to Basquiat, the name originated from a stoned conversation with Diaz, in which they called the marijuana that they smoked the “same old shit”.



The theme of the song also plays to comments Vince recently made in an interview with LA Weekly:

If a photographer took the same picture over and over again, you’d call them crazy, right? If an architect built the same house, if a designer made the same clothes, if a painter made the same painting—we’d all discredit them,” Vince explains. “Then why do we expect musicians, and rappers specifically, to do the same thing over and over and over? It’s because they do not look at rap music as art. They like to say the word, but they’re not really holding anything to those standards.”

In a video of him touring Long Beach Vince says that he wouldn’t have done music without guys named Dijon Samo and Chuck Wun– the song title could also be a shout out to Samo.

songs.title: New earlsweatshirt (Interlude)

description.plain:
The fifth track off Vince’s FM! project, New earlsweatshirt (Interlude) marks Earl Sweatshirt’s first CDQ verse since his feature on “Really Doe” in 2016.

Earl appears for a quick interlude where he discusses a range of topics, from Crips, being sent to Samoa and friends and family who have passed away.

songs.full_title: Feels Like Summer by Vince Staples
songs.title: Feels Like Summer

description.plain:
The opening track to FM! celebrates the summer feeling present year round in Vince’s hometown of Long Beach, CA, where it is mostly sunny.

But Vince also wants to tell us that even though summer time is fun, it is also dangerous. And that Long Beach can also be a dangerous place year round.

songs.title: Party People

description.plain:
Vince Staples lives a sober life, staying away from drugs and alcohol, as he mentioned in a 2015 reddit AMA, as he stated, “I will never do drugs.”

Although Staples stays away from substances, he is still aware of his own anxiety and suicidal thoughts.  While delving into his inner feelings, he also uses this track to get people to feel the vibrations on another groovy and body-moving beat from Zack Sekoff.

description.plain:
In “Homage,” Vince Staples depicts his life and success as a rapper while demonstrating any shortcomings or obstacles will not faze him.  Staples also contradicts his life as a musician with his life outside of music as a normal human being on this track.

Here, Staples interpolates Rick Ross' “Hold Me Back”, hence the title “Homage”.

songs.full_title: Birds & Bees by Vince Staples (Ft. Daley)
songs.title: Birds & Bees

description.plain:
For the fourth track Vince morphs a childhood saying into a gangsta’s anthem over a DJ Dahi beat. Vince describes the typical lifestyle one has embedded in them at a young age, the one Vince has coming from his father. In an interview with The FADER he said:

This is the thing—I really did all of that, so I know it’s not fun and cool. It sucks. Nobody likes that shit. I got homies calling me from jail telling me they want to get home and get their shit together, and I know they can’t. That sucks.

songs.full_title: Tweakin' by Vince Staples (Ft. Buddy & Kehlani)
songs.title: Tweakin’

description.plain:
Featuring vocals from Buddy and Kehlani, “Tweakin'” is a sinister track about Vince’s lifestyle and the commonness of his friends passing away. Vince has talked before about the deaths of his close friends and the effects of gang violence, especially on songs like “Guns and Roses” off his mixtape Stolen Youth, a collaboration with the late rapper Mac Miller.

“Tweakin'” marks the first collaboration between Vince and Kehlani. Vince teased the collaboration on November 1, 2018 on his Twitter. https://twitter.com/vincestaples/status/1058198330100961287

songs.full_title: Like It Is by Vince Staples
songs.title: Like It Is

description.plain:
Summertime ‘06 comes full circle, continuing the theme presented in track 2 “Lift Me Up”, of Vince wanting to ascend from the hell on earth that is the ghetto.

The track contains a vocal sample from DJ Drama’s “The Art of Storytellin' Part 4” featuring OutKast and Marsha Ambrosius. The sample is taken from André 3000’s verse.

songs.title: Street Punks

description.plain:
In Vince’s seminal braggadocious piece off of Summertime ‘06, he draws the distinction between himself, a real “street punk” and those who only act or appear to be that way.

On May 6, 2018, this song was used at the conclusion of Season 3, Episode 7 of Showtime’s acclaimed drama “Billions,” when hedge-fund king Bobby Axelrod is vindicated from his legal troubles and returns home.

A braggadocios & mafioso track about gang culture, a common theme in Vince’s catalog.

The producer of this track, James Blake, has worked on critically acclaimed albums like Lemonade by Beyoncé and Blonde by Frank Ocean.

This is the first time that Vince and James have collaborated, as Vince told Zane Lowe:

songs.title: Might Be Wrong
songs.title_with_featured: Might Be Wrong (Ft. Haneef Talib & James Fauntleroy)

description.plain:
In this song, Staples explores rising murder rates and gang violence in his hometown of Long Beach, California; he seeks to understand the systematic injustices around him.

In an interview with Exclaim, Staples explained:

I don’t know what to blame: Is it stereotypes? Is it perception? Is it race? Is it humanity? The problem that I have with all those things is that it’s not ‘this person just killed another person.’ It’s ‘this white cop killed a black man, this black man killed a black man, this Mexican man killed a black man, this Spanish man killed a black man, this black man killed a Spanish man.’ Why does that matter if people are dying? Why aren’t people just hurting people? What does wrong really mean? It’s all based on the window you’re looking out of.

songs.title: Pimp Hand

description.plain:
This is the sixth track on Prima Donna. In this song, Staples comments on how the old have no business in judging the current hip hop scene. He says that they should leave it to the youth to determine the future of the craft.

 In his interview with Zane Lowe, Vince revealed that he recorded this song in 2015. Over the variety of topics that Staples raps on in Prima Donna, this was more blunt and biased.

description.plain:
As we approach the release of Vince Staples' debut album Summertime ‘06, his label Def Jam provides his second single, “Get Paid”.

Vince certainly has “money on his mind” and enlists fellow Long Beach native Desi Mo to assist him on the hook. The label head and executive producer of his album, the legendary No I.D., provides the beat harnessing the classic West Side sound with a set of banging drums.
